articles.headline: Libyan Rebels Advance; U.S. Will Deploy Drones
articles.snippet: Rebels seized a Tunisian border crossing as President Obama authorized the use of armed drones against Qaddafi’s forces.
articles.abstract: Rebels seized a Tunisian border crossing as President Obama authorized the use of armed drones against Qaddafi’s forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi suffered setbacks on multiple fronts on Thursday as rebels in the western mountains seized a Tunisian border crossing, fighters in the besieged city of Misurata said they were gaining ground and President Obama authorized the use of armed drones for close-in fighting against the Qaddafi forces.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: After Years of Red Flags, a Conviction
articles.snippet: Lee B. Farkas, guilty in a $2.9 billion mortgage lending scandal, had this to say about his fraudulent operations: “It happens all the time.”
articles.abstract: Lee B. Farkas, guilty in a $2.9 billion mortgage lending scandal, had this to say about his fraudulent operations: “It happens all the time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2002, when Lee B. Farkas was running a relatively small mortgage company, it got caught selling eight fraudulent mortgages to Fannie Mae. To make things even worse, the mortgages — all of which defaulted without a single payment being made — listed Mr. Farkas as the borrower.

articles.headline: Nation’s Mood at Lowest Level in Two Years, Poll Shows
articles.snippet: Americans’ pessimism about the economy and the nation’s direction is hurting the ratings of President Obama and Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.
articles.abstract: Americans’ pessimism about the economy and the nation’s direction is hurting the ratings of President Obama and Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are more pessimistic about the nation’s economic outlook and overall direction than they have been at any time since President Obama’s first two months in office, when the country was still officially ensnared in the Great Recession, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Senator Ensign to Resign Amid Inquiry
articles.snippet: Senator John Ensign of Nevada, a Republican who had been caught up in a sex scandal and an ethics inquiry, announced he is planning to resign before his term ends.
articles.abstract: Senator John Ensign of Nevada, a Republican who had been caught up in a sex scandal and an ethics inquiry, announced he is planning to resign before his term ends.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John Ensign of Nevada, the subject of an ethics investigation related to his affair with the wife of a former top aide, announced Thursday evening that he was resigning, effectively ending the high-profile Senate inquiry that had already ruined his once-promising political career.

articles.headline: A Clash Over the Airwaves
articles.snippet: The government wants TV broadcasters to give up some of their airwaves to allow for expanded use by cellphones and other mobile applications.
articles.abstract: The government wants TV broadcasters to give up some of their airwaves to allow for expanded use by cellphones and other mobile applications.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Dropped calls. Maps that take eons to load. Echoing voices on a mobile phone. And, as iPhone users know, the dreaded “Cannot Open Page.“

articles.headline: Finland’s Turn to Right Sends Shivers Through Euro Zone
articles.snippet: The obscure True Finns party grabbed a share of the government in elections last week after campaigning on the evils of the European Union and its bailouts of Greece and Ireland.
articles.abstract: The obscure True Finns party grabbed a share of the government in elections last week after campaigning on the evils of the European Union and its bailouts of Greece and Ireland.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — There is hardly a country on the continent that has been a more steadfast supporter of the European Union than Finland. For more than 20 years, the voters here have returned the same three parties to power in various coalition governments, with few changes in policies.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and James Kanter

articles.headline: As Consumers Cut Spending, ‘Green’ Products Lose Allure
articles.snippet: As recession gripped the country, the consumer’s love affair with green products faded like a bad infatuation.
articles.abstract: As recession gripped the country, the consumer’s love affair with green products faded like a bad infatuation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Clorox introduced Green Works, its environment-friendly cleaning line, in 2008, it secured an endorsement from the Sierra Club, a nationwide introduction at Wal-Mart, and it vowed that the products would “move natural cleaning into the mainstream.”
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Obama Makes His Case in Mostly Friendly Territory
articles.snippet: President Obama showcased his achievements during his two-day trip to the West Coast, raking in millions of dollars for the Democratic Party.
articles.abstract: President Obama showcased his achievements during his two-day trip to the West Coast, raking in millions of dollars for the Democratic Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Obama confronted head-on the frustrations of his liberal base during a two-day West Coast trip, but also got plenty of evidence in sentiment and dollars that the love is still there — not least because of fear of the alternative that Republicans pose.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Security Forces Kill Dozens in Uprisings Around Syria
articles.snippet: Security forces met thousands of demonstrators with fusillades of live ammunition after noon prayers, killing at least 81 people in the bloodiest day of the Syrian uprising.
articles.abstract: Security forces met thousands of demonstrators with fusillades of live ammunition after noon prayers, killing at least 81 people in the bloodiest day of the Syrian uprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Security forces in Syria met thousands of demonstrators with fusillades of live ammunition after noon prayers on Friday, killing at least 81 people in the bloodiest day of the five-week-old Syrian uprising, according to protesters, witnesses and accounts on social networking sites.

articles.headline: Toyota Says No Full Production Until Year’s End
articles.snippet: The time frame was the longest yet described by the car company to recover from Japan’s quake and tsunami.
articles.abstract: The time frame was the longest yet described by the car company to recover from Japan’s quake and tsunami.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota Motor will not return to predisaster production levels until the end of the year, the president of the Japanese automaker said Friday.

articles.headline: China Curbs Fancy Tombs That Irk Poor
articles.snippet: Some local governments would like those who succeed not to lord it over others, at least when it comes to paying final respects.
articles.abstract: Some local governments would like those who succeed not to lord it over others, at least when it comes to paying final respects.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — Ever since Deng Xiaoping signaled in 1978 that it was fine to get rich, much of China has seemed hell-bent on that goal. But some local governments would like those who succeed not to lord it over others, at least when it comes to paying final respects.
